text: COMMITTEE ENDS TWO INEFFECTIVE PROGRAMS AND STOPS THE SPENDING OF $30 BILLION
label: HH3

text: WASHINGTON (March 10) – The House Financial Services Committee, chaired by
label: BODY

text: Congressman Spencer Bachus (AL-6), approved legislation on Wednesday that ends two
label: BODY

text: ineffective government spending programs. The bills, which terminate the troubled Home
label: BODY

text: Affordable Modification Program (HAMP) and the Neighborhood Stabilization Program (NSP),
label: BODY

text: prevent more than $30 billion in additional spending on the programs.
label: BODY

text: Approval by the Committee moves the bills forward for consideration by the House.
label: BODY

text: Financial Services Committee Chairman Bachus said, “The American people sent us here
label: HH1

text: to tell them the truth, and the truth is our country is in serious trouble because of excessive
label: BODY

text: government spending.  We are on an unsustainable path that will lead to ruin, that will lead to a
label: BODY

text: diminished standard of living for our children and grandchildren, and that will reduce the
label: BODY

text: greatness of our country.  We must take action immediately to change course and put a stop to
label: BODY

text: this reckless culture of spending that has ruled Washington for far too long.”
label: BODY

text: The Financial Services Committee approved the following two bills:
label: BODY

text: H.R. 839, the HAMP Termination Act
label: BODY

text: H.R. 839, introduced by Rep. Patrick McHenry (NC), terminates Treasury’s authority to provide
label: BODY

text: new assistance under HAMP while preserving the contracts made prior to the bill’s enactment.
label: BODY

text: H.R. 839 prevents $29 billion in TARP funds from being spent to continue this ineffective
label: BODY

text: program. Far from helping at-risk homeowners, HAMP has actually put many struggling
label: BODY

text: homeowners in worse financial shape.  As the Special Inspector General for TARP (SIGTARP),
label: BODY

text: Neil Barofsky, reported in testimony to a subcommittee, HAMP “benefits only a small portion of
label: BODY

text: distressed homeowners, offers others little more than false hope, and in certain cases causes
label: BODY

text: more harm than good.”
label: BODY

text: Rep. McHenry said, “The Home Affordable Modification Program, or HAMP, was created to
label: HH1

text: stave off the foreclosure crisis and aid troubled borrowers.  But here we are two years later and
label: BODY

text: all who investigate, analyze, or survey this program conclude that it is an epic failure.  The
label: BODY

text: COMMITTEE ENDS TWO INEFFECTIVE PROGRAMS AND STOPS THE SPENDING OF $30 BILLION
label: HH3

text: government is offering false hope to hundreds of thousands Americans, and it just can’t deliver.”
label: BODY

text: HAMP was announced by the Administration in February 2009 and $30 billion in TARP dollars
label: BODY

text: were set aside for HAMP. The Administration claimed HAMP would help up to 4 million
label: BODY

text: homeowners. Instead, only 521,630 loans have been permanently modified and the re-default
label: BODY

text: rate is high. From the $30 billion earmarked for HAMP only $840 million has gone out the door.
label: BODY

text: There is widespread criticism that HAMP is not working and is only making matters worse for
label: BODY

text: many of the homeowners who participate or seek to participate. In addition to the SIGTARP, the
label: BODY

text: Congressional Oversight Panel and the Government Accountability Office have detailed
label: BODY

text: problems with HAMP.
label: BODY

text: H.R. 861, the NSP Termination Act
label: HH1

text: H.R. 861, introduced by Rep. Gary Miller (CA), terminates the NSP and prevents an additional
label: BODY

text: $1 billion from being spent on this program, which has already consumed nearly $6 billion. The
label: BODY

text: NSP does nothing to help struggling homeowners stay in their homes.  Instead, it allows lenders
label: BODY

text: and real estate speculators to off-load their foreclosed properties onto the taxpayers.
label: BODY

text: The Inspector General for the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) has
label: BODY

text: identified multiple cases of misuse of NSP funds, and the Government Accountability Office has
label: BODY

text: said HUD does not have proper tools in place to keep track of uses of the funds.
label: BODY

text: Subcommittee Chairman Miller said, “I am pleased the Committee has voted to terminate the
label: HH1

text: Neighborhood Stabilization Program (NSP). We have little to show for the nearly $6 billion of the
label: BODY

text: taxpayers’ money that was spent on this ineffective program.  NSP was inefficient and it did not
label: BODY

text: target resources to those areas with the most need.  Even worse, there was no requirement for
label: BODY

text: repayment of the allocated funds.  At a time when the national debt has surpassed $14 trillion
label: BODY

text: and the federal government is borrowing 40 cents for each dollar spent, it is imperative that we
label: BODY

text: stop wasting taxpayer dollars on such ineffective and unaccountable government programs.
label: BODY

text: The best way to address the foreclosure crisis and stabilize communities is to get our economy
label: BODY

text: back on track.”
label: BODY

text: COMMITTEE ENDS TWO INEFFECTIVE PROGRAMS AND STOPS THE SPENDING OF $30 BILLION
label: HH3
